column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: In February 2023, Stockland welcomed 36 graduates into its two-year Graduate Program, reflecting its focus on building its talent pipeline. Stockland achieved a diverse representation of graduates with a balanced gender split. Stockland's unique option to 'Create Your Future' allows graduates to craft their program and gain experience across various roles in its business. Stockland's graduate program has been awarded a Top 100 program by GradConnection for seven consecutive years and, over the last two years, has received similar awards by Prosple and the Australian Association of Graduate Employers.
column20: Graduate Program, talent pipeline, gender split

column6: New employee hires and employee turnover
column13: Every 12-18 months, Stockland conducts talent reviews to assess its employee population to identify people with the highest potential to develop into more senior leadership roles. For Stockland's most senior leader populations (Executive General Managers and General Managers), this includes considering those who could be future members of the Stockland Leadership Team. The talent review process allows Stockland to target its investment to key populations, tailoring their development and providing visibility and support to further their career at Stockland.
column20: Talent review, employee population, senior leadership

column6: Benefits provided to full-time employees that are not provided to temporary or part-time employees
Parental leave
Parental leave
column13: Stockland's parental transition program supports its people before and during their parental leave to help them stay informed and connected throughout this important stage of their careers. Managers and employees maintain a continued focus on career development during this time. Additionally, employees are partnered with a mentor who has previously been on parental leave to provide guidance and support where desired. Keeping in Touch Days allows Stockland's people to stay connected with important business updates and transitioning advice.
column20: Parental transition program, parental leave, career development

column6: Parental leave
column13: Stockland understands that raising a child impacts all parents, whether they are the primary or secondary carer, biological, adoptive, surrogate or long-term foster parents, regardless of gender. As a family-friendly workplace, eligible employees, regardless of gender, may take up to 20 weeks of paid parental leave (or up to 40 weeks of paid parental leave at half pay) in one continuous block, multiple blocks or a part-time capacity over 24 months. Noting this can be at the same time as their partner to ensure equal opportunity for all Stockland people.
column20: Stockland Paid Parental Leave, primary carer, secondary carer

column6: Minimum notice periods regarding operational changes
column7: The Managing Director and CEO and Other Executive KMP are on rolling contracts until Stockland or the senior executive gives notice of termination. The Managing Director and CEO notice period is twelve months and six months for Other Executive KMP. In appropriate circumstances, payment may be made in place of notice.

column6: Occupation health and safety management system
Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Stockland's Work Health and Safety Policy details commitments that support its vision to foster a culture of CARE (Community, Accountability, Respect & Excellence). Work undertaken by Stockland employees is typically limited to low-risk professional, domestic and maintenance duties. Following the acquisition of Halcyon, this profile has changed with the supervision of construction work and dedicated landscape teams. In line with this risk profile, Stockland employee incidents typically include manual handling-related injuries, ergonomic-related injuries, muscle strains/sprains and slip/trip/fall incidents.
column20: Work Health and Safety Policy, CARE, risk profile

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Stockland's health and safety management system was originally designed and structured based on AS/NZS 4801 and has continued to evolve with the creation of ISO45001, which was introduced in 2018. Stockland developed and implemented a multi-layered approach to managing WHS and operational risk in all business units across operations and development. This multi-layered approach is a network of periodic internal and external audits, workplace inspections, incident investigations, property and general liability risk audits by insurers and numerous other compliance and risk management initiatives.
column20: Health and safety management system, multi-layered approach, risk audit

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: WHS, contractor safety, and customer safety are governed by Stockland's Integrated Management System RISC (Risk & Assurance, Insurance, Safety and Compliance), an internally developed system implemented nationally. RISC defines Stockland's approach to managing operational risk and includes compliance with associated regulatory requirements. Stockland's risk management framework also includes business continuity plans for its assets and insurance management for its business, including workers' compensation insurance.
column20: Integrated Management System RISC, operational risk, risk management framework

column6: Hazard identification, risk assessment, and incident investigation
column13: Stockland's national Operational Risk Assurance Program incorporates WHS and ascertains compliance with operational risk procedures. The Operational Risk team monitors and reports progress against audit action items. Stockland's WHS systems are reviewed periodically by external legal and WHS consultants. Reviews often follow legislation and relevant standards changes but also occur as needed informally.
column20: Operational Risk Assurance Program, operational risk procedure, audit action item

column6: Occupational health services
Worker participation, consultation, and communication on occupational health and safety
Worker training on occupational health and safety
Worker training on occupational health and safety
column13: In FY23, Stockland trained 30 mental health peer supporters across its business to support a positive mental health environment in its workplaces. These voluntary, non-clinical roles are trained to work collaboratively with their peers to help recognise signs of distress, listen to concerns and refer colleagues who could benefit from additional support.
column20: Mental health peer training, mental health, non-clinical role

column6: Promotion of worker health
Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Stockland recognises the role flexibility plays in employee health and well-being. Stockland's flexibility strategy focuses on making flexibility business as usual. Stockland's position is that all roles are considered flexible where possible. Stockland's commitment to flexible working is designed to make it easier for employees to continue to develop a successful career while balancing other commitments outside of work.
column20: Flexibility strategy, health, well-being

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Stockland values the benefits of flexible work and continues evolving its flexibility approach. Stockland's hybrid working model is an enterprise approach to flexibility involving working in assets, offices, local workplaces and at home or remote locations. Leaders and teams build plans aligned with Stockland's principles. Each team develops working rhythms aligned with Stockland's recommended blueprint, highlighting the importance of face-to-face collaboration for complex problem-solving and learning.
column20: Hybrid working model, flexible work, flexibility approach]

column6: Prevention and mitigation of occupational health and safety impacts directly linked by business relationships
column13: Stockland monitors the safety performance of contractors on its development sites. Stockland developed a Serious Incidence Response Plan with a range of key initiatives in recognition of the fact that global supply chain issues and labour shortages are affecting contractor safety performance. The initiatives include independent audits, stop-work meetings, commercial property safety briefings, and civil and infrastructure on-site safety training.
column20: Serious Incidence Response Plan, safety performance, safety training

Average hours of training per year per employee
column7: Stockland's average training days are 1.6 days per employee.

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Stockland launched Future Ready Careers as part of its reimagined learning and development strategy. The program expands opportunities for learning and opens up career pathways for Stockland's people. Being Future Ready at Stockland means developing seven key capabilities: customer centricity, adaptive mindset, collaboration and teamwork, judgement and decision making, building high-performing teams, leading change, and enterprise leadership.
column20: Future Ready Careers, development strategy, career pathway

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Stockland introduced a new partnership with LinkedIn Learning to enable its people to learn as they work. LinkedIn Learning is an educational platform that helps employees develop business, technology-related, and creative skills through expert-led course videos.
column20: LinkedIn Learning, educational platform, course video

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: In FY23, Stockland held its first Innovation Week, spotlighting innovators across the business and demonstrating the strong link between ESG and innovation. Stockland also extended its people's digital and data capabilities with theoretical and targeted practical learning experiences around data, robotic process automation, and the emerging generative artificial intelligence (AI) area.
column20: Innovation Week, innovator, ESG

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: Stockland's Capability Masterplan sets out the broad range of capabilities that enhance the effectiveness of its people and the collective organisation. Stockland's learning and development programs and resources focus on building these capabilities, specifically the self-leadership and leadership capabilities, and business and technical capabilities for specific job families.
column20: Capability Masterplan, development program, self-leadership

column6: Programs for upgrading employee skills and transition assistance programs
column13: The Future of Work Group is led by passionate, strategic leaders and experts who chart the path forward for Stockland to become a leader in the Future of Work, both for Stockland employees and Stockland's workplace tenants. It is a functional group that researches and pilots innovative solutions to shape Stockland's workplace ecosystem and culture.
column20: Future of Work Group, strategic leader, workplace tenant

column6: Percentage of employees receiving regular performance and career development reviews
Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Stockland's Diversity and Inclusion strategy is supported by four focused Employee Advocacy Groups (EAGs) across Gender Equity, LGBTQ+, Cultural Diversity, Well-being and Disability. These groups include employees at various levels in the organisation and from various backgrounds to encourage diversity of thought, more representative decision-making, and improved delivery of Stockland's initiatives.
column20: Employee Advocacy Groups, Gender Equity, LGBTQ+

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Stockland's Diversity and Inclusion Policy outlines how it enables its people to achieve their maximum potential, irrespective of age, gender identity, gender expression, sexual orientation or intersex status, physical ability and attributes, non-visible disabilities, ethnicity, family status or beliefs.
column20: Diversity and Inclusion Policy, gender, sexual orientation

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Stockland's accessibility strategy advocates for improved recruitment of people with a disability and supporting accessibility in the workplace. Stockland partners with the Australian Network on Disability to provide undergraduates with work experience through its Stepping Into Internship program. Stockland focuses on ensuring Stockland is a disability-confident employer.
column20: Stepping Into Internship, accessibility strategy, Australian Network on Disability

column6: Diversity of governance bodies and employees
column13: Stockland's LGBTQ+ strategy promotes inclusion for its people, customers and communities. Stockland aims to enhance its positioning as an employer of choice for LGBTQ+ people. Stockland utilises its benchmark results from the Australian Workplace Equality Index to build and execute a targeted strategy.
column20: Workplace Equality Index, LGBTQ+, employer of choice
